intro: Astragalus illinii, commonly known as Illinois milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the central United States. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in dry, open habitats such as prairies and rocky slopes. The plant produces small, yellowish to reddish flowers arranged in clusters, and its leaves are palmately divided into several leaflets. It is part of the legume family, Fabaceae, and has the ability to fix nitrogen through symbiotic relationships with soil bacteria. Astragalus illinii is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators.
